Courtine*, E. Bordes Ddpartement de Ggnie Chimique, Universiti de Technologie de Compi~gne, BP 529, 60205 Compikgne Cedex, France Abstract Vanadium oxide or V-containing systems are extensively used as components of various catalysts used in mild oxidation, ammoxidation and dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons and other organic compounds. The discussed examples are the definite phases (V-P-O, butene and butane oxidations), supported bulk and monolayers (V-Ti-O, o-xylene oxidation), and mixed oxides (V-Mo-Nb--O, ethane oxidation). The common structural features are commented. Heteropolya- cids, which can be stabilized either on structurally related heteropolysalts or on silica doped with potassium, are also considered as they contain similar molecular sites. The model of coherent interfaces, proposed to explain the synergic effects exhibited by most of these catalysts, is discussed and compared with concepts of other authors. Keywords: Vanadia; Oxidation catalysis I. Introduction The catalytic properties of vanadium oxide in mild oxidation of hydrocarbons are known since 1960s. The first reactions to be performed industrially were o- xylene oxidation to phthalic anhydride and benzene oxidation to maleic anhydride [ 1-6]. Although V205 was found to be active in several reactions of mild oxidation, soon it has been recognized that the addition of other elements was a good means to improve its properties. According to their amount in the V2Os-MxOy system, these elements can be considered as promoters (e.g. V2Os-Pd in oxidation of ethylene to acetaldehyde) [7], or as supports (e.g. V2Os-TiO2 in o-xylene oxidation to phthalic * Corresponding author. 0926-860X/97/$17.00 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. PII S0926-860X(97)00020-3 46 P. Courtine, E. Bordes/Applied Catalysis A: General 157 (1997) 45-65 anhydride) [1--4] when in large excess. In other cases, definite phases like, e.g. vanadyl pyrophosphate (M---P) or magnesium vanadate (M=Mg), are formed, which show distinct properties in n-butane to maleic anhydride and propane to propene reactions, respectively. In few cases mixed oxides are found, as in the system V2Os-MoO3-Nb205 active in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane [8], and microdomains are expected to account for their special properties [9,10]. Rather than to give an exhaustive list of these modified V205 catalysts which have been extensively studied or are described in the present issue, we have chosen to emphasize the role of coherent interfaces which is important from both fundamental and applied points of view. Therefore we shall consider some typical and distinct examples of catalysts in which the driving forces governing the activity and selectivity have to be discussed in terms of interfacial properties [11,12]: 1. The P/V=I: 1 phases of the [V2Os-P2Os] system in the oxidation of butenes and n-butane to maleic anhydride. A large number of papers have been devoted to this subject [13-21]. We shall restrict ourselves to some of the structural properties of (VO)2P207 when it is alone during the oxidation of n-butane and when it is found beside VOPO4 in the oxidation of butenes. 2. The properties of V205 when supported as "bulk" or as monolayer on TiO2. Three polymorphic forms of TiO2, anatase, rutile and TiO2(B), have been used as supports in several oxidation reactions: o-xylene to phthalic anhydride [1-4,22-34], butene and butadiene to maleic anhydride [35,36], butene to acetic acid [37], toluene to benzoic acid [38], methanol and ethanol to aldehydes [39-41] and others [44,45], and also in ammoxidation of alkyl aromatics [42,43]. The kinetics and mechanism of these reactions are known because olefins and aromatics are very reactive as compared to alkanes, and the structural and surface properties of the corresponding catalysts have been examined by numerous techniques. 3. The VzO5 mixed oxides containing other ReO3-1ike oxides such as MoO3 and Nb205. Examples are chosen in the oxidative dehydrogenation and oxidation of ethane [8-10,46-51]. 4. Finally, a very different example of vanadium containing catalyst is given by the polyoxovanadomolybdates. Polyoxomolybdates are used extensively for their acid and redox properties [52-60]. Adding vanadium to H3PMo12040 leads to HaPVMo11040 which is then more active and selective in the oxidative dehydrogenation of isobutyric acid to methacrylic acid. Supports were recently proposed to stabilize these Keggin structures which are not thermally stable on stream [60-64]. Although the molecular structure of polyoxometallates is very different at first sight from the above considered polymeric vanadia structures, interfaces between support and active phase can be analyzed in similar ways. P. Courtine, E. Bordes/Applied Catalysis A: General 157 (1997) 45~55 47 2. The (VO)2P207/VOP04 system In 1987, Sleight et al. [65] noticed that it could be very interesting to know why (VO)2P207, one of the P/V=I : 1 phases of the system, is always present beside VOPO4 in the active catalyst for oxidation of butenes [14,65] while alone it is so selective in the oxidation of n-butane to maleic anhydride [16-20]. In the latter case, XRD patterns of fresh catalysts exhibit only (VO)2P207 lines. However, several studies have shown that the average oxidation state of vanadium in the most active and selective catalyst is slightly above 4.00, which means that some V5+ (formal valence state) are present. The presence of V4+-O bonds has been thought necessary to break the C-H bond and activate the alkane, while V4+ (Lewis acid sites) would activate dioxygen [21]. Indeed, the available electron in the V4+ (dL) orbital could allow the formation of the chemisorption bond since, contrary to the case of olefins or aromatics, there is no 7r-electron in n-butane which could play this role [12]. Oxygen linked to V5+ would then ensure the oxygenation of the intermediate, leading to maleic anhydride. An important question is to know where these V5+ species are located. One way to answer consists in considering the formal valence states of vanadium in (VO)2P207 because in each pair of edge- sharing octahedra the length of the vanadyl V=O bond is different: 1.73 and 1.55 A (mean values) correspond to V4+ and V5+, respectively, as found in other V5+ (e.g. VOPO4) and V4+ (e.g. VOSO4) related phases [12,19,65]. Before considering other interpretations, it is necessary to recall that a special preparation is used to obtain selective (VO)2P207 for n-butane oxidation. Owing to the topotactic nature of the dehydration of the layered precursor VOHPO4.0.5H20, pseudomorphic crystals of (VO)2P207 exhibit mostly (1 0 0) faces [67-69]. It has been shown that the control of the operating parameters during the preparation of the precursor (which affect its crystal morphology) leads to the control of the crystal morphology of the catalyst [70]. However, the operating parameters during calcination and activation are very determinant for the catalytic properties at steady state and for ageing of the catalyst. Depending on these conditions, different shapes, relative intensities and FWHM (Full Width at Height Medium) of XRD lines were observed, which account for strains and crystallite size effects. Two groups of researchers have recently addressed this point. Ebner and Thompson [71 ] synthesized two kinds of (VO)2P207 single crystals, one emerald-green and one red-brown with very close cell parameters (Table 1), but exhibiting some differ- ences in their Raman spectra. Let us recall that, using infrared spectroscopy, we had already observed significant differences between samples of (VO)2P207 obtained by reduction of /3-VOPO4 and by dehydration of VOHPO4.0.5H20 [67]. Their reactivity was also different since, by reoxidation,/3-VOPO4 and 7- VOPO4 were obtained, respectively [72]. The structural differences apparent in the green and red crystals were thought to be likely those which had been identified in microcrystalline catalysts, and thus to relate to the ordering of the metal atoms within the structure [71 ]. In this case, there is no need to add another element, nor to invoke the existence of interfaces between an oxidized and a reduced phase, although this was proposed in a former work [18,20]. The situation is different in the case of butene which is much more reactive than n-butane, so that the catalyst has neither to be prepared by a particular way, nor to contain a maximum amount of hard acid P. The active phase is the VS+-containing phase, VOPO4, which ensures the activation of butene by formation of the 7r-allylic complex on V5+ (3d sites. The formation of (VO)2P207 is only the result of the reduction of VOPO4 by butene [14,63,67]. Gravimetric experiments showed indeed that in catalytic conditions (1% butene in air at 450C) the mean stoichiometry of the catalyst at the steady state is VPO4.7. Therefore, the optimal catalyst works as a biphasic system containing microdomains of the oxidized phase, o~- or/~-VOPO4, and of the reduced one, (VO)2P207, according to the Mars and van Krevelen mechanism [66,76]. This mechanism must proceed on neigh- boring sites situated at the boundaries between microdomains of VOPO4 and (VO)2P207. The severe activation barrier between two solid phases is lowered only if the interface is coherent, which means that the surface energies are low enough to allow the transfer of electrons and other species (H, O, etc.) through the interface. Owing to the structural analogies between the lattice planes of the two phases, coherent interfaces between them were indeed thought to be built, until the steady state was reached [11,76]. It must be noticed that on (VO)2P207 itself the CMAS model [21] shows that butene would be adsorbed by its C=C bond on under- saturated oxygens, yielding non-selective by-products. 3. The V2Os/TiO2 system The extent of work on this subject is very large and has been reviewed in several papers [1-4]. We shall recall here the main results obtained on bulk and monolayer supported vanadium oxide catalysts, in order to discuss the validity of the model of coherent interfaces. Because this model has been either partially used or poorly understood, we take the opportunity to come back on it and on the subsequent experiments made to improve it. 3.1. Supported bulk catalysts More than 20 years ago, it has been found that TiO2 (anatase) used as a support for V205 catalyst was responsible for increasing its activity and selectivity in the oxidation of o-xylene to phthalic anhydride [1-4]. At this time, no monolayer catalyst was used. The model of coherent interfaces has been drawn to account for this synergic effect [11,77]. This model is essentially based on the a priori observation that the structures of V205 and TiO2 (anatase) are closely related. Using the concept of coherent interfaces already known to apply in other fields (e.g., semiconductors), and in solid state chemistry [78], it is proposed that the low crystallographic misfit between cleavage planes of V205 and TiO2 (anatase) would be responsible for the lowering of surface energy allowing various species to cross the interface. Therefore, a low misfit (few percents) is to be considered as a pre- requisite condition to observe synergy. Whatever the actual interface is, the atoms 50 P. Courtine, E. Bordes/Applied Catalysis A: General 157 (1997) 4545 on boundaries are strained, so that their activity is greater than when they are inside the phases. Indeed, in numerous cases of synergic effect, the activity is increased and reaches a maximum at a given composition, while the selectivity is only slightly affected. Another important point is that synergy is observed also in non- catalytic reactions, so that any direct influence of the organic phase is ruled out. In 1970s, Cole et al. [23] and V6jux et al. [77] observed that V205 could be reduced when supported on TiO2 in conditions (N2, 600) which normally do not allow reduction to proceed. Simultaneously, anatase was transformed into rutile with a very low activation energy (15 instead of 150kcal mo1-1) [79]. It has been assumed that the cleavage plane (0 1 0) of V205 is anchored on the (0 0 1), (1 0 0) and (0 1 1) planes of anatase with a very small crystallographic misfit, while similar anchoring would be less easy with rutile because of higher misfit and different pattern. To demonstrate the validity of the concept, other phases structurally related, and between which the calculated misfit is a priori low, were used as supports. Other oxides and oxysalts were as well deposited on Tit2 anatase. Indeed, the reactivity of V205 supported on A1NbO4, GaNbO4 and ZiNb207 and on TiO2(B) was found to be modified, the extent of reduction depending on the support used. For example, in isothermal conditions and in nitrogen, the reduction of V205 supported on TiO2(B) proceeds faster than when VEt5 is supported on anatase (Fig. 1). Moreover, TiOE(B) is transformed partly into anatase at 525 and totally into rutile (through anatase) at 600 after 20 h [80]. When TiO2 anatase was used as a support for other oxides like MoO3 or oxysalts like, e.g. CoMoO4, the partial conversion of TiO2 anatase to rutile was observed [81]. The behavior of V205 supported on titania structurally related phases is also modified in catalytic conditions [33,82]. During the oxidation of o-xylene, Tit2 remains as anatase since the temperature is less than 450. But because of the reducing atmosphere and during the transient state, the successive suboxides of V205 (the cleavage plane patterns of which are similar to V205) are formed by crystallographic shear (CS) plane mechanism. The reduction stops near the V6013 stoichiometry [24,25], the formation of which corresponds to an optimal value of the crystallographic misfit between V205 and TiO2 anatase, and then the steady state is reached because of an optimal strain factor. Discussion and conclusion In the various examples of supported or mixed oxide catalysts, except the case of heteropolyacids, common features are exhibited by the active crystalline phases which are related to activity and selectivity in mild oxidation reactions [ 11,12,76]: (i) The presence of transition metal ions having high formal charges, such as V5+, V4+, Mo6+, Mo5+, Nb5+, with easy change of valence and coordination. Redox couples such as Vs+/v4+ or Mo6+/Mo5+, are adapted to a Mars and van Krevelen kinetic mechanism. (ii) Layered morphology, and low Tammann temperature allowing wetting and/ or spreading onto supports for vanadia catalysts. t~ Courtine, E. Bordes/Applied Catalysis A: General 157 (1997) 45-65 61 (iii) Close structural relationship with ReO3 structure, even for the support. The consideration of the bulk properties as a guide is fruitful, even in the case of monolayers, as seen below. (iv) Mechanism of reduction by nucleation of crystallographic shear planes allowing extended defects to be formed (also valid for VOPO4); deeper reduction can also proceed during the transient state. Owing to these common features, microdomains, the interfaces of which can be coherent, can be formed during the transient state and be kinetically but not thermodynamically stable during the steady state. Complex oxide systems com- posed with three ReO3-1ike phases fulfilling the preceding conditions, i.e. V205, MoO3 and Nb205 can be more active for a given composition for which the number and quality of contacts is supposed to be optimum. Mixed oxides of ReO3-type with Nb205 have been proposed for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane, which showed interesting selectivities at low conversion [ 105-107]. However, the chemistry of solid phases in heterogeneous catalysis is a rather low temperature chemistry. In the very well crystallized phases synthesized at high temperature, for the synthesis of superconductors for instance, boundaries of microdomains are very well defined by HRTEM. It is difficult in our cases to show by electron microscopy whether the microdomains boundaries are coherent or not. As underlined by Haber [87], the dynamic state of oxide surfaces is also to be taken into consideration. When the cohesion energy of an oxide is smaller than its adhesion energy to the surface of another oxide, its migration over the surface support can occur as the manifestation of "wetting", and spontaneous "spread- ing" takes place. However, this phenomenon is more general (provided the Tamman temperature is low) and does not lead always to synergic effects in catalysis or in non-catalytic conditions. Such effects are seen, for example in oxidation of o-xylene, with V205]TiO2 but not when V205 is supported on alumina, although spreading can be observed [88]. An alternative concept is proposed by Delmon et al. who explain the synergy effect by the spillover of oxygen. Oxygen would be activated at the surface of a "donor"-type oxide and supplied through this spillover to the surface of the "acceptor"-type oxide, thus generating new active centers which accelerate the reaction. This concept was applied, e.g., to the N-ethyl formamide dehydration on the [MoO3-Sb204] system at 350-390 [108-110]. In this case the Tammann temperature of the two oxides in contact is very low. If it is still difficult to fully characterize the surface of a solid, it is at least possible to foresee by the knowledge of its morphology and crystal structure, not only what are the surface lattice planes statistically exposed, but also the structural relationships between the surface and the bulk or, at least, of the few layers below the surface. For example, the crystal structure of both V205 and TiO2 (anatase form) are closely related and derive from a cubic compact arrangement, whereas the rutile structure is very different since it derives from a hexagonal compact arrangement. Therefore it is logical to think that the bidimensional arrangement of 62 P. Courtine, E. A spreading of V205 was found possible indeed on the surface of anatase but not on the surface of rutile [32,95], whereas SEM showed that platelets of V205 crystallites were growing perpendicularly to rutile surface [78]. It can be added that the surface polyvanadates found on monolayer supported catalysts are in fine closely related to the chains of edge-shared octahedra found in V205. When monolayer catalysts began to be studied, their reactivity seemed com- pletely different from that of bulk catalysts. There is no doubt that polyvanadates are active in many reactions, including the oxidation of ethane to acetic acid [50]. But one could ask why and how monomeric tetrahedral species like those found at low coverage could be selective enough so as to provide the 12 electrons and six oxygens (three for phthalic anhydride and three for water formation) in the selective oxidation of o-xylene. Another striking point is the low availability of oxygen (one oxygen released by vanadium) exhibited by monolayers. It could be normal that the similar behavior was found whatever the support when studying methanol oxidation to formaldehyde, which is a poorly demanding reaction (2-e exchanged, one O to make water). On the other hand, many authors that we have cited have shown that "amorphous" surface layers of octahedrally distorted vanadia were displayed on the surface of anatase. Such an arrangement seems more appropriate for highly demanding reactions. With a similar idea in mind, we proposed that dimeric species structurally close to those in (VO)2P207 would bring more selectivity than the kind of chains in V205 because of site isolation due to the presence of phosphate groups [50]. Taking into account the redox mechan- ism which may lead, at the end of the transient state, to a more or less reduced catalyst which actually works at the steady state, it is always necessary to characterize the spent catalyst and not only the fresh one. A good example is provided by the work of Centi et al., [86], who finally showed that the behavior of their bulk supported catalysts was exactly comparable after 1000 h to that of the monolayer samples. It is worthwhile to consider the case of supported heteropolyacids. These molecular entities could be supposed at first to behave differently from the layer, polymer-like oxides examined above. However, the easy adaptation of the amount of water and protons between the Keggin units according to the degree of hydration and to the kind of reaction results in a remarkable "elasticity" of the heteropolyacid lattice allowing its anchoring on suitable supports. This seems to be the case when K-doped cristobalite or heteropolysalts K3PMo1204o are used as supports, so that the lattice of the heteropolyacid adopts a cubic symmetry. In conclusion, from these recent findings, one could say that a classification of monophasic or multiphasic mild oxidation catalyst begins to emerge, even if a full understanding of the surface and interracial phenomena occurring in these reac- tions is not yet straightforward. Vanadium oxide or V-containing systems are extensively used as components of various catalysts used in mild oxidation, ammoxidation and dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons and other organic compounds. The discussed examples are the definite phases (VPO, butene and butane oxidations), supported bulk and monolayers (VTiO, o-xylene oxidation), and mixed oxides (VMoNbO, ethane oxidation). The common structural features are commented. Heteropolyacids, which can be stabilized either on structurally related heteropolysalts or on silica doped with potassium, are also considered as they contain similar molecular sites. The model of coherent interfaces, proposed to explain the synergic effects exhibited by most of these catalysts, is discussed and compared with concepts of other authors. coredata.dc:description: Vanadium oxide or V-containing systems are extensively used as components of various catalysts used in mild oxidation, ammoxidation and dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons and other organic compounds. The discussed examples are the definite phases (VPO, butene and butane oxidations), supported bulk and monolayers (VTiO, o-xylene oxidation), and mixed oxides (VMoNbO, ethane oxidation). The common structural features are commented. Heteropolyacids, which can be stabilized either on structurally related heteropolysalts or on silica doped with potassium, are also considered as they contain similar molecular sites. The model of coherent interfaces, proposed to explain the synergic effects exhibited by most of these catalysts, is discussed and compared with concepts of other authors.
